title: How many books did Napoleon Bonaparte read? - Quora

response.answer_text: A lot. He was a voracious reader, to the extent that he actually travelled with his (portable) library! He literally always travelled with books and took great interest into getting the best portable library possible. He read a lot. He read all the philosophical classics, such as The Prince by Machiavelli, Montaigne’s Essays, Plato’s Republic, Jean-Jacques Rousseau’s oeuvre, and many, many others. He also read a lot about ancient history, especially Livy and Plutarch. His favourite work was The Lives of the Noble Grecians and Romans by Plutarch, which shouldn’t be too surprising, if you know about his love for the old Greeks and Romans. All of the above doesn’t even take into account his actual studies at the military school at Brienne, where he studied the new tactics that he would later apply so successfully. Not only the amount that he read, but also the breadth of his reading habits is striking. Not surprisingly, he read about military tactics, philosophy and history — as mentioned above, but also travel stories (Cook), poetry — with Homer being his favourite, religious texts (the Bible, the Quran,…),…

Napoleon was a very big reader. It is impossible to know the exact number, but from what I remember, he read:Rousseau - La Nouvelle Héloïse, the Social Contract Voltaire’s biography of Charles XII Montesquieu, Plutarch’s lives, Montaigne’s Essays, Livy, Cornelius Nepos, Tasso’s Jerusalem Delivered, Homer, the Bible, Quran, Tacitus, a biography of Admiral Nelson, Edward Gibbon’s Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, Paul and Virginia, Corneille, Racine, Julius Caesar’s De Bello Gallico and his other works, Arrian’s Alexander the Great, Herodotus, Polybius, the military campaigns of Turenne, Condé, Eugene of Savoy, Frederick the Great, Villars, Marlborough, Julius Caesar, Hannibal, and Alexander the Great, Voltaire’s Mahomet, Ossian, Plato, Cicero, and Virgil.
